user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_increment_response_rc:
```c
void
MHD_increment_response_rc (struct MHD_Response *response)
{
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
  MHD_mutex_lock_chk_ (&response->mutex);
#endif
  (response->reference_count)++;
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
  MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_ (&response->mutex);
#endif
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
  MHD_mutex_lock_chk_ (&response->mutex);
#endif
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: Not violated. The MHD_mutex_lock_chk_ call is conditionally included via the preprocessor (#if). Code excluded by the preprocessor is not "unreachable" — it is simply not part of the translation unit. When MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS or MHD_USE_W32_THREADS is defined the lock call is compiled and reachable at runtime. A true Rule 2.1 violation would be code that can never be executed in any compiled configuration (for example code guarded by an always-false constant expression such as if (0) { ... }), which is not the case here.
